title: 114_hr3295
content:
The Department of Justice is appropriated $140,000,000 for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance, including funds for various programs such as the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program, Drug Courts, mental health courts, programs to reduce gun crime and gang violence, and veterans treatment courts program. $10,000,000 is allocated for Juvenile Justice Programs for community-based violence prevention initiatives, focusing on public health approaches to reduce shootings and violence. Additionally, funding is provided for Community Oriented Policing Services programs. $30,000,000 is allocated for Community Oriented Policing Services Programs, with $15,000,000 for State law enforcement agencies in high-seizure States for precursor chemicals and methamphetamine, and $15,000,000 for statewide law enforcement agencies in high opioid admission States for investigative purposes related to heroin and opioid distribution. INDEPENDENT AGENCIES

Small Business Administration: Additional funding for entrepreneurial development programs and business loans program account.

DEPARTMENT OF LABOR

Employment and Training Administration: Additional funding for training and employment services.

DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES

Health Resources and Services Administration: Additional funding for maternal and child health through the Healthy Start Initiative. The Health Resources and Services Administration received $50,000,000 for the Healthy Start Initiative for maternal and child health. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration received $10,000,000 for substance abuse treatment. The Department of Housing and Urban Development received $170,000,000 for the Choice Neighborhoods Initiative. The Community Planning and Development fund received additional funding. An additional $500,000,000 is allocated for the Community Development Fund until September 30, 2016, for emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in distressed areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Funds will be granted to distressed communities with insufficient capacity to recover, based on measurable criteria like racial segregation and low employment levels among youth. The Community Development Fund allocates $500,000,000 for emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in distressed areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Grantees must submit a plan detailing fund usage and eligibility criteria to address long-term recovery and restoration of infrastructure, housing, and economic revitalization. The Secretary will specify approval criteria within 45 days of enactment, and plans not meeting criteria will be disapproved. The Secretary will specify approval criteria for plans within 45 days of enactment. Plans not meeting criteria will be disapproved. Grantees must incorporate performance requirements and penalties into contracts. The Secretary may waive or specify alternative requirements for statutes or regulations in connection with fund usage. The Secretary may waive or specify alternative requirements for contracts or agreements related to fund usage, except for certain specified provisions. Up to 30% of funds can be used for immediate community assistance, and up to $10,000,000 may be transferred for program office salaries. The funds are allocated for immediate community response, recovery, and revitalization assistance. Up to $10,000,000 can be transferred for administrative costs of overseeing the funds. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes is allocated an additional $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. General provisions include moving-to-work initiatives. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes receives an extra $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. Moving-to-Work agreements for housing agencies are extended until 2028 with certain conditions and reporting requirements. The Act designates each amount as an emergency requirement, subject to the President's subsequent designation and transmission to Congress. The Act is also known as the "Rebuilding Urban Inner Cities Is Long Overdue Act of 2015" or the "REBUILD Act."
